item.title: Irreducible Complexity and Design Discourse
item.description: Even if Michael Behe's analysis fails as an inductive argument, there is good reason to think complex biological systems were designed.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Fine Tuning
item.description: The universe gives every appearance of having been fine-tuned to support the existence of humans. Neither the so-called anthropic prinicple nor a many-worlds hypothesis provide good alternative explanations to Christian theism.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Classical Mechanics Doesn't Exclude Miracles
item.description: Some philosophers and theologians have supposed that classical mechanics excludes God's acting in the world specially (i.e. miracles). This is nonsense of the highest order.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Realism and Antirealism
item.description: Critical scientific realism, though it has serious challenges, is the best explanation of the success of science and model of scientific knowledge. Applying this to the question of creationism yields helpful insights into the debate.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Full-On Question-Begging
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

Scientific naturalism, as a worldview (not an instrumental technique applied in certain circumstances) is certainly question-begging. First, the claim that “the physical world is the only thing which exists” is fundamentally …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Empirical Equivalence, Real Semantic Difference
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

When two theories make contradictory claims, even were they to have empirically equivalent outcomes, the contradiction in their claims is not merely terminological or semantic. It is fairly easy to conceive …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Realism, Generality, and Precision—In Tension?
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

The tension between realism, generality, and precision posited in biology is a function not of those constraints in general, but of the specific constraints on biology and other sciences dealing with …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Aristotle, Newton, and Progress
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

Aristotle’s impetus theory provided an effective and predictively accurate (and indeed, scientific) model of the behavior of objects in terrestrial contexts. Though it was later superseded by Newton’s model …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Statistical Regularities and Explanation
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

It is easy to mistake exactness for explanatory power in the realm of explanation. Thus, it might be tempting to suppose that precise and consistent statistical regularities have greater explanatory power …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Counterfactuals and Supervenience
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

The natural sciences all claim to use the same basic model of knowledge, and claim to aim for the same kind of explanatory power: the law. However, clearly the kinds of …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Science and Pseudo-Science
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

Many differences do not admit of clear or hard distinctions. The difference between science and pseudo-science is just such a difference. There is a clear and intuitively obvious difference between astronomy …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Corpuscularianism and Atomism
item.description:
The following was prepared as a one-page, single-spaced short response to a question from the readings for this class.

One possible point of difference between philosophy and science is the way they proceed toward answering questions and understanding the world. For example, “Corpuscularianism was mere philosophy. Atomism is science,” suggests …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Realism and Anti-Realism in Science
item.description: The realism/anti-realism debate in science often hinges on the nature of and relationship between observables and unobservables. But is there actually such a distinction?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: The 'Covering Law' Model
item.description: The 'covering law' model of scientific explanation demands explanations be deductive arguments with sound premises referring to natural laws. It founders on the issue of causality.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: The Problem of Induction
item.description: Is induction a trustworthy means of obtaining knowledge? The majority of scientific reasoning necessarly leans heavily on induction—but is this warranted or defensible?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho
